title: Safari crasheds now!
content:
I used Safari 1.3 v312 on OS-X 10.3.9 and today it doesn’t load webpages and then hangs.

IE and Firefox work just fine.

I think others have had such issues all of a sudden. Have you ? How come?

vincent connare

comments.content: Vince, I updated the day it was released and have had no problems. What else did you install?

I stopped using Safari and switched to Camino which is by the mozilla guys but a dedicated mac browser which runs quicker on my ibook than firefox did but still has tabbed browsing and prevents pop ups.

[http://www.caminobrowser.org/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526123509/http:/www.caminobrowser.org/)

Your problem sounds unusual to me, unless you run any Safari add-ons. Many of them aren’t compatible with Safari 1.3.

Otherwise, you might want to ask on the Apple boards.

I re-run I-Life 5.0 and see if Safari is on that. The download Safari install also doesn’t work… it starts and background of installer shows but no information words on buttons or anything so it hangs too.

Apple toy life… poo
I-Photo 5.0 no longer imports photos and crashes too. I-Life 5.0 is Harold Shipman.
I had read that there were some crashing problems with design applications with the new Tiger OS. Has anyone else installed Tiger and had problems launching apps?

No all of my apps work perfectly well and I installed tiger a week ago, my machine ran slow for the first couple of days but now its much quicker with hardly any slow down at all, even when I have indesign, Photoshop and illustrator open at the same time, where as it used to be quite slow.

I upgraded without a hitch. Everything’s faster, and all my design apps run fine.

Spotlight has already come in handy several times too. Just make sure you let it finish its initial indexing before you do any serious work.

Quartz Composer (which comes with the developers’ tools) is very cool. You can design and play back complex animations and effects that render right on the graphics processor.

I haven’t heard of any bungled Tiger upgrades, Vince. If you’re having trouble, talk to Apple. They didn’t get ranked #1 in computer customer service by hanging customers out to dry.

Vince, have you rebooted your Mac since the initial installation of the update?

Sometimes a second reboot will force all of the automatic system-level maintenance scripts to run and do a bunch of stuff that needs to happen on a regular basis.

It really sounds like you need to run a system utility like [Cocktail](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526123509/http:/macosxcocktail.com/) or [OnyX](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526123509/http:/www.macupdate.com/info.php/id/11582) to clean your application and system cache files and repair permissions. Something has caused some file access problems with a few of your applications. You shouldn’t need to reinstall anything. If you are unable to download and install a new program like Cocktail, then boot your Mac off the original OS X CD that came with it and run the Disk Utility from the CD. It will allow you to repair permissions at least.

the Installer for I-Life 5.0 CD and the Safari installer start up but hang.. So no Apple installers or Applications now work. So I have to try you Cocktail or Onyx.

This Mac is about 2 months old and hardly used usually once ever other day for an hour. It’s a G4 12” Powerbook… toy.

I installed Tiger and my biggest annoyances come with Safari, which has a bunch of buggy quirks now. I had some problems with Illustrator and Photoshop CS not copying and pasting between each other (it dropped some weird error), but after some restarts and poking it just went away.

Other than that, I’m happy with it. Now I just need more RAM.

Oh, none of my Safari/design app problems are crashes. It’s weird window behavior and scroll bar freakouts.

Related: An update, 10.4.1, was just released today. Hit your ‘Software Update…’ option in the Apple menu. Apparently, many of the fixes are related to “3rd party mice with scroll wheels”, according to a friend of mine.

It’s quite low level since I reinstalled the system. and still nothing worked from Apple only 3rd party apps work. All installers, system update, system prefs or apple installers crash or hang. So It’s time (after 3 months with a new machine) to nuke the hard drive.

Vince, have you tried getting help over at Apple’s support discussion forum? There’s a special area for sorting out problems with Tiger:

[http://discussions.info.apple.com/webx?14@290.PhjBavYaWdQ.0@tiger](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526123509/http:/discussions.info.apple.com/webx?14@290.PhjBavYaWdQ.0@tiger)

You might have better luck there than on Typophile.

Nuking the hard drive seems like a rather drastic step (although I have the impression that it is a routine solution in the Windows world).

I’m not sure how appropriate it is in your case but there is advice about debugging Safari in MacUser this month, I don’t have it to hand so I can’t tell you exactly what it said but apparently by adding a line of text in Terminal you can reveal a debug menu option in Safari.  
Tim
